poem:
Under the cracked neon of Route 21’s sign,  
a diesel heart thumps against empty pavement.  
Morning fog drips from its mirrors,  
ghostly limbs reaching for the curb.

It rumbles forward,  
steel jaws parting rush-hour crowds,  
churning hot air into the city’s lungs.  
You can taste the grit on your tongue—  
ash, asphalt, ambition.

Inside, fluorescent lights flicker  
like distant thunder,  
illuminating faces half-asleep, half-expectant.  
A lone possum darts across the lane—  
no mercy here.  
The bus barrels on,  
unshaken by pleading eyes or tiny paws.

It whispers to the streetlamps,  
spinning yarns of hidden tunnels  
beneath subway grates,  
of midnight riders who vanish  
beneath marble pillars.  
It claims to have carried kings and thieves,  
to have outraced sirens and outwitted fog.

Wheels clatter in a constant chant,  
a metallic heartbeat calling each stop home.  
Skyscrapers lean in,  
their glassy eyes reflecting that pulsing arc—  
twentieth-century dreams locked in steel.

At every intersection, red lights burn like warnings,  
but the bus’s gaze is unwavering.  
It draws a clean line through the city’s chaos,  
a ribbon of conquest  
binding corner to corner.

The driver tips a nod to brick walls and billboards,  
to the scent of fresh-baked bread drifting  
from a bakery down the block.  
The bus inhales the city’s stories  
and exhales legends of its own making.

At dusk, the route glides beneath flickering streetlights,  
echoes of laughter and footsteps  
trapped in its undercarriage.  
It bears the weight of every journey—  
promise and promise broken—  
and keeps moving,  
unyielding,  
unyielding.
